Sentence-English: Next Saturday is my father's 60th birthday.

Comment: Used in class as "brew", to make using boiling water

Vocab-English: stand up; rise; sit up / get up

Comment: Remember here "work" is a concept, not a place. "Going to do the concept of working"
Literally "Morning Meal" can be shorted to "아침"
에 Location marking particle, 가다 to go
Literally to go to the location that is the bathroom
Used with pure Korean number - 두번째 -> Second
Can be combined with Nouns to make verbs (Ex. Food to do -> Do the food thing -> To Eat)
Can be added after other verbs to make a "Please [Verb]" type sentence
'-지만' is attached to the root of a verb, adjective, or ‘noun + 이다’ to indicate that the following clause is in contrast to the preceding clause.
A word used to change the direction of a story while relating it to the preceding statement.
A word used to connect two statements that are opposite in meaning to each other.
A conjunctive adverb used when the following statement is conditional upon the preceding one.
Sentence-English: Hurry up or else you’ll be late.

Sentence: 그를 만나면 이 쪽지 좀 전해 줘.
Sentence-English: If you see him, give him this note.
Sentence-Sound: [sound:그를 만나면 이 쪽지 좀 전해 줘..mp3]

Comment: When you use ‘그래서’ between two sentences, it means that the former sentence is the reason for the latter sentence.
Sentence: 우리가 아주 바빠요. 너무 그래서 올해는 쉴 시간을 못 낼 것 같아요.
Sentence-English: We are very busy—so much so that we won’t be able to take time off this year.
Sentence-Sound: [sound:우리가 아주 바빠요. 너무 그래서 올해는 쉴 시간을 못 낼 것 같아요..mp3]

Comment: A postpositional particle used to indicate that the preceding word refers to grounds for doing something.
For that reason, or therefore / To begin with.
Sentence: 그러니까 당신이 그들의 제의를 받아들일 수도 있군요?
Sentence-English: So you might accept their offer?
Sentence-Sound: [sound:그러니까 당신이 그들의 제의를 받아들일 수도 있군요.mp3]

Comment: Can be used in list format: Noun도, Noun도
Mnemonic: The 차 (car) 고 in the garage!

Vocab-English: (polite form) Another person's home or family.
